name: 課程理論專題研究
description:
本課程為教育系博士班課程與教學組之理論基礎課程，透過對當代重要課程論述的研讀與討論，本課程企圖達到的目標如下：
(一)探討課程理論的歷史發展脈絡。
(二)認識重要課程學者的理論主張及其影響。
(三)認識當代課程論述的多元內涵。
(四)比較不同課程理論主張/多元課程論述文本的差異與價值。
(五)探究課程理論與實務間的關係。
(六)反省個人課程信念/重建個人課程理論。
goals: 探討課程理論的歷史發展脈絡。
認識重要課程學者的理論主張及其影響。
認識當代課程論述的多元內涵。
比較不同課程理論主張/多元課程論述文本的差異與價值。
探究課程理論與實務間的關係。
反省個人課程信念/重建個人課程理論。
syllabus:
**Week 1   Course Introduction/Examining Beliefs about Curriculum**

\*Macdonald, J. B. (1982). How literal is curriculum theory? _Theory into Practice_, 31(1), 55-61.

**Week 2   Concepts of the Curriculum/Key Aspects of Curriculum Studies**

Ross, A. (2000). What is the curriculum. In _Curriculum construction and critique_ (pp. 8-17). London: Falmer Press.

Kelly, A. V. (1999). The curriculum and the study of the curriculum. In _The curriculum: Theory and practice_. (4th Ed.). (pp. 1-22). London: Paul Chapman.

\*Kliebard, Herbert M. (1975). Persistent curriculum issues in historical perspective. In In W. Pinar (Ed.). _Curriculum theorizing: The reconceptualist_. (pp. 39-50). Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

**Week 3   About Curriculum Theorizing and its Development**

Kliebard, H. M. (1992). Curriculum theory: Give me a “for instance.” In _Forging the American curriculum: Essays in curriculum history and theory_. (pp. 168-182). New York: Routledge.

Schubert, W. (2002). Curriculum literature and its authors: More thoughts after 20 additional years of pondering. In W. H. Shubert, A. L. Lopez Shubert, T. P. Thomas & W. M. Carroll (Eds.). _Curriculum books: The first hundred years_ (2nd ed.), (pp. 501-527). New York: Peter Lang.

Thomas, T. P. ＆ Schubert, W. H. (1997). Recent Curriculum Theory: Proposals for Understanding, Critical Praxis, Inquiry, and Expansion of Conversation. _Educational Theory_, 47(2):261-285.

**Week 4   Traditionalists Perspectives on Curriculum**

Bobbitt, Franklin (1918). Scientific method in curriculum-making. In D.J. Flinders & S. J. Thornton (Eds.), (1997). _The curriculum studies reader_ (pp. 9-16). NY: Routledge.

Tyler, Ralph W. (1975). Specific approaches to curriculum development. In J. Schaffarzick & D. H. Hampson (Eds.). _Strategies for curriculum development_. (pp.17-33). Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

\*Kliebard, Herbert M. (1975). The rise of scientific curriculum-making and its aftermath. In Flinders, D. J. & Thornton, S. J. (Eds.). (2004). _The curriculum studies reader_ (2nd Ed.) (pp. 37-46). New York: RoutledgeFalmer

**Week 5   Conceptual-Empiricists Perspectives on Curriculum**

Schwab, Joseph J. (1962). The concept of the structure of a discipline. In Giroux, H., Penna, A. & Pinar, W. (Eds.). (1981). _Curriculum and instruction: Alternatives in education._ (pp. 51-61). Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

Johnson, Jr. Mauritz (1967). Definitions and models in curriculum theory. _Educational Theory_. 17(2), 127-140.

\* Schwab, Joseph J. (1969). The practical: A language for curriculum. _School Review_, 78(1), 1-23.

**Week 6   Re-conceptualist Perspectives on Curriculum****（I****）**

Macdonald, James B. (1975). Curriculum and human interests. In In W. Pinar (Ed.). _Curriculum theorizing: The reconceptualist_. (pp. 283-294). Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

Huebner, Dwayne (1967). Curriculum as concern for man’s temporality. _Theory into Practice_, 6(4), 172-179. Reprinted in W. Pinar (Ed.), _Curriculum theorizing: The reconceptualists_ (pp. 237-149). Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

Greene, Maxine (1975). Curriculum and consciousness. In W. Pinar (Ed.). _Curriculum theorizing: The reconceptualist_. (pp. 299-317). Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

**Week 7   Re-conceptualist Perspectives on Curriculum** **（II****）**

Apple, Michael W. (1971). The hidden curriculum and the nature of conflict. _Interchange_, 2(4), 27-40.

Willis, George (1975). Curriculum theory and the context of curriculum. In W. Pinar (Ed.). _Curriculum theorizing: The reconceptualist_. (pp. 427-442). Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

Giroux, Henry A. (1979). Toward a new sociology of curriculum. _Educational Leadership_, 37, 248-253.

\* Pinar, William F. (1978). The reconceptualization of curriculum studies. _Journal of Curriculum Studies_. 10(3), 205-214.

\* Macdonald, James B. (1971). Curriculum theory. In W. Pinar (Ed.). _Curriculum theorizing: The reconceptualist_. Berkeley, CA: McCutchan.

**Week 8   midterm report in process – individual exploration**

**Week 9   midterm report** **─** **台灣課程期刊與學術論文的20****年發展趨勢分析（單一課程文本分析為主）；或選擇一本課程經典研讀原文並參酌相關評述進行深究與評述。**

**Week 10  Social/Political/Gender Texts about Curriculum Theorizing**

Bowers, C. (1980). Curriculum as cultural reproduction: An examination of the metaphor as carrier of ideology. _Teachers College Record_, 82(2), 267-290.

Apple, M. W. (2000). Standards, markets, and curriculum. In B. M. Franklin (Ed.). _Curriculum and consequence_ (pp. 55-74). New York: Teachers College Press.

Noddings, N. (1992). Gender and the curriculum. In P. W. Jackson (Ed.). _Handbook of research on curriculum_. (pp. 659-684). NY: Macmillan.

\*Dillabough, J. (2006). Gender Theory and Research In Education – Modernist Traditions and Emerging Contemporary Themes.  In M. Arnot and M. Mac an Ghaill (eds.) The RoutledgeFalmer Reader in Gender and Education.  London and New York: Routledge.

**Week 11  Phenomenological/ Autobiographical Text about Curriculum Theorizing**

van Manen, Max (1982). Phenomenological pedagogy. _Curriculum Inquiry_, 12(3), 283-299.

Grumet, Madeleine R. (1992). Existential and phenomenological foundations of autobiographical method. In W. Pinar & W. Reynolds (Eds.). _Understanding curriculum as phenomenological and deconstructed text_ (pp.28-42). NY: Teachers College Press.

Schubert, William H. (1992). Practitioners influence curriculum theory: Autobiographical reflections. _Theory into Practice_. 31(3), 236-244.

**Week 12  Institutionalized Text about Curriculum Theorizing**

Goodlad, John I. & Su, Zhixin (1992). Organization of the curriculum. In P. W. Jackson (Ed.). _Handbook of research on curriculum_. (pp. 327-344). NY: Macmillan.

Clandinin, J. & Connelly, M. (1992). Teacher as curriculum maker. In P. Jackson (Ed.), _Handbook of research on curriculum._ (363-401). NY: Macmillan.

Erickson, F. & Shultz, J. (1992). Students’ experience of the curriculum. In P. Jackson (Ed.), _Handbook of research on curriculum._ (465-485). NY: Macmillan.

**Week 13  Postmodern/Aesthetic Text about Curriculum Theorizing**

Doll, Jr., William (1989). Foundations of a postmodern curriculum. _Journal of Curriculum Studies_, 21, 243-253.

Slattery, P. (1995). Postmodern schooling, curriculum, and the theological text. In P. Slattery, _Curriculum development in the postmodern era_. (pp. 67-99). New York: Garland Publishing.

Broudy, H. S. (1988). Aesthetics and the curriculum. In W. F. Pinar (Ed.), _Contemporary curriculum discourses_. (pp.332-342). Scottsdale, AZ: Gorsuch Scarisbrick.

\* Slattery, P. (1995). Postmodern education: Kaleidoscopic sensibilities. In P. Slattery, _Curriculum development in the postmodern era_. (pp. 243-257). New York: Garland Publishing.

**Week 14  Emerging Themes in Contemporary Curriculum Theorizing -- Pedagogy and learning with ICT**

Kerr, Stephen T. (1999). Visions of Sugarplums: The future of technology, education, and the schools. In M. Early & K. Rehage (Eds.). Issues in Curriculum: Selected essays from NSSE yearbooks. Chicago, ILL: NSSE.

Somekh, B. (2006) New Ways of Teaching and Learning in the Digital Age: Implications for Curriculum Studies. In A. Moore (ed.) Schooling, Society and Curriculum (pp.119-129). London and New York: Routledge.

McFarlane, A. (2006) ICT and the Curriculum Canon: Responding to and exploring ‘alternative knowledge’. In A. Moore (ed.) Schooling, Society and Curriculum (pp.130-142). London and New York: Routledge.

**Week 15  Emerging Themes in Contemporary Curriculum Theorizing****－Curriculum in Popular culture**

Ellsworth, E. (1989). Educational Media, Ideology, and the Presentation of Knowledge Through Popular Cultural Forms. In H. A. Giroux and R. I. Simon (eds.) _Popular Culture, Schooling and Everyday Life_ (pp.47-66). New York: Bergin & Garvey.

Fisher, R., Harris A. & Jarvis, C. (2008). “Introduction,” in _Education in Popular Culture: Telling Tales on Teachers and Learners_ (pp.1-44). London and New York: Routledge.      

\*Giroux, H. A. & Simon, R. I. (1989). Popular culture as a pedagogy of pleasure and meaning. In H. A. Giroux and R. I. Simon (eds.) _Popular Culture, Schooling and Everyday Life_ (pp.1-30). New York: Bergin & Garvey.

**Week 16  Emerging Themes in Contemporary Curriculum Theorizing - The Implication of Globalization in curriculum theorizing**

Waks, L. J. (2003).  How Globalization can cause fundamental curriculum change: An American Perspective.  Journal of Educational Change, 4: 383-418.

Osler, A. (2006). New Directions in Citizenship Education- Reconceotualizing the curriculum in the context of globalization.

**Week 17  final report in process – individual exploration**

**Week 18  Final Report of Personal Curriculum Theorizing / New Trends in Curriculum Theorizing –**（How do we “see” learners in our curriculum theorizing? What are the possible implications for policy-makers, school leaders, and teachers?）
